subject: Technology
title: Collaborative Filtering: Why You See What You See
description: A short lesson to help you apply Collaborative Filtering: Why You See What You See.

hook.text: If you and a stranger both liked the same five movies, the algorithm bets you'll like the stranger's sixth movie too.

buildup.text: Collaborative filtering finds patterns in behavior across millions of users. People who act alike probably like similar things.

discovery.text: Netflix uses this to recommend shows. Spotify uses it for playlists. Amazon uses it to suggest what you should buy next.

twist.text: This creates filter bubbles. You only see content similar to what you already like, narrowing your perspective over time.

climax.text: Collaborative filtering is powerful but invisible. It quietly shapes your tastes, beliefs, and purchasing decisions.

punchline.text: The algorithm knows your taste better than you do. That's the problem.

quiz.question: What is a filter bubble?
options: When algorithms only show you content similar to what you already like
